item.title: 你的大脑仍以为你在被掠食者追赶
item.description:
你拿到年度绩效评估。十条正面反馈，一条改进建议。三天后，你唯一记得的只有那条批评。赞美呢？并非完全遗忘，但当听到需要改进之处时，赞美瞬间就失去了分量。努力回想或许能记起，却远不及负面评价那般刻骨铭心——后者会烙印在大脑完全不同的区域。 这并非性格缺陷，而是普遍存在的负面偏好现象。研究者们在不同文化、年龄、地域和情境中都验证了这一点。2001年鲍迈斯特团队的实验分析显示：相较于同等程度的中性或积极事件，负面事件会激发更强烈的情绪反应、更持久的思维反刍，并对行为产生更深远的影响。 这种差异并非微不足道。在亲密关系研究中，约需五次积极互动才能抵消一次负面冲突的影响。记忆实验表明，即使时隔数周，人们对负面图像的回忆依然比积极画面更鲜明生动。 大脑如此演化自有其道理。万年前，错过好消息（远处树上的成熟果实）不过损失一餐，忽略坏消息（灌木丛中的捕食者）却会丧命。自然选择不在乎幸福舒适，只优化生存机制——那些将模糊阴影都视为潜在威胁的祖先，才最终延续了基因。 问题在于环境演变快过了神经回路。如今我们不再搜寻捕食者（除非身处荒野），却转而刷着社交平台、研读绩效评估、核对银行余额。

This isn’t a personality flaw. It’s negativity bias, and it’s universal enough that researchers have tracked it across cultures, age groups, locations and contexts. A 2001 study by Baumeister and colleagues analyzed hundreds of psychology experiments and found that bad events produce more emotion, more persistent thoughts, and stronger impacts on behavior than neutral or good events of similar magnitude.

The ratio isn’t subtle. In relationship research, it takes roughly five positive interactions to balance one negative interaction. In memory studies, people recall negative images more vividly than positive ones even weeks later.

Your brain evolved this way for a reason. Ten thousand years ago, missing a piece of good news (ripe fruit in a distant tree) cost you a meal. Missing bad news (predator in the brush) costs you your life.

Natural selection didn’t optimize for happiness, and it didn’t care about your comfort. It optimized for not dying. The humans who survived long enough to become your ancestors were the ones whose brains treated every ambiguous shadow as a potential threat.

The problem is that the environment changed faster than the wiring. You’re not scanning for predators anymore, at least not for those that can eat you, unless you are living somewhere in the wilderness. So you’re scrolling X, Insta, TikTok, reading performance reviews, checking your bank balance.

你的威胁检测系统却未更新评估机制。它仍将社会批评视作人身危险，把不确定性当成迫在眉睫的攻击，让任何负面信息都持续占据注意力的焦点。世界变得更安全了，但你的大脑并未收到通知。如今这种错位在你每次人际互动中悄然运行。九句赞美随风逝，一句批评刻心间。当大脑接收九条正面评价与一条负面评价时，正面评价经由奖励系统处理——这个系统天生擅长发现美好，然后迅速翻篇。多巴胺短暂飙升带来愉悦感，随后系统立即重置，因为在进化逻辑里，满足感是危险的。一旦感到满足，你就会停止搜寻威胁。负面评价则驶向完全不同的轨道。它直击杏仁核——这个位于大脑颞叶深处的杏仁状微小结构从不重置。杏仁核专职威胁侦测，其记忆存储远长于奖励系统，且发声更为响亮。2003年一项采用功能磁共振成像的PET激活研究发现，负面图像在杏仁核引发的活跃度显著高于正面或中性图像，且持续时间更长。招聘场合同样可见此现象。管理者习惯性高估候选人的负面信息：一封平庸的推荐信能抵消三封强力推荐，简历上一个小小空白比五年扎实业绩更引人注目。我至今记得2010年的案例：招聘委员会花40分钟讨论候选人某个弱点，仅用5分钟谈及优势，却声称自己"同等考量"了所有方面。亲密关系亦不例外。伴侣们总是放大负面互动：晚餐后一次冷淡回应能抹杀三周的温情付出，一次遗忘的纪念日比五年如一日的陪伴更令人耿耿于怀。

The world got safer, but your brain didn’t get the memo. And now that mismatch is running in the background of every interaction you have.

Nine compliments vanish, one criticism sticks

When your brain gets nine positive comments and one negative one. The positive comments get processed through your brain’s reward system, which is designed to notice good things and then move on. Dopamine spikes briefly, and you feel pleased. Then the system resets because, in evolutionary terms, contentment is dangerous. If you’re satisfied, you stop looking for threats.

The negative comment goes somewhere else entirely. It hits your amygdala, a small, almond-shaped structure within the brain’s temporal lobe, which doesn’t reset. The amygdala’s job is threat detection, and it has a much longer memory than your reward system. It’s also louder. A 2003 study (A PET Activation Study) using fMRI scans found that negative images produced significantly more activation in the amygdala than positive or neutral images, and that activation lasted longer.

You can see this in hiring, too. Managers routinely overweigh negative information about candidates. One mediocre reference outweighs three strong ones. One gap in a resume gets more attention than five years of solid performance. I still remember a case in 2010 where hiring committees spent 40 minutes discussing a candidate’s single weakness and five minutes on their strengths, then claimed they gave both “equal consideration.”

You can see this in relationships, too. Partners routinely overweigh negative interactions. One cold response after dinner outweighs three weeks of warmth and effort. One forgotten anniversary gets more attention than five years of showing up consistently.

在信息不全的情况下做决定，偏见会加剧。大脑会用威胁假设来填补信息空白。老板的沉默会被解读为不满，同事走神会被当成对你生气，一封模棱两可的邮件会被读出最负面的语气——这正是大脑的运作机制。 在刻意利用这种模式的环境里，偏见会加速形成。社交媒体呈现的并非人类行为的真实样本，而是最能引发互动的极端内容，而负面内容往往比正面内容更具煽动性。愤怒的传播速度总是快过喜悦。 2018年麻省理工学院研究《网络真假新闻传播》追踪了推特（现X平台）12.6万条新闻发现，假新闻的传播速度是真新闻的六倍，主因在于假新闻往往更负面、更新奇。你的信息流不是现实的窗口，而是大脑杏仁核无法忽视的猎奇窗口。 感恩日记、强颜欢笑、策略性回避——应对负面偏见的常规建议分为三类，但照单全收只会适得其反。第一种方案是忽略负面信息。其逻辑在于既然大脑会高估坏消息，就该有意识降低其权重。把批评当杂音，专注积极面。这招在遇到真正重要的负面信息时会失灵：账户透支、项目延期、关系恶化。因习惯性忽略负面信号而忽视真实问题，会让小隐患演变成大灾难。我们都曾因忽视小问题而酿成大祸，多年后仍追悔莫及。If you don’t have complete information, your brain fills in the gaps with threat assumptions. Silence from your boss becomes evidence of disapproval. A colleague’s distraction becomes a signal they’re upset with you. An ambiguous email gets read in the most negative plausible tone. This is exactly how our brain works.

And the pattern accelerates in environments designed to exploit it. Social media platforms don’t show you a representative sample of human behavior. They show you whatever generates engagement, and negative content generates more engagement than positive content. Outrage spreads faster than joy.

A 2018 MIT study “The spread of true and false news online” tracked 126,000 news stories on Twitter (now X) and found that false news reached 1,500 people six times faster than true stories, largely because false news tended to be more negative and more novel.

Your feed isn’t a window into reality; it’s sadly a window into what your amygdala can’t ignore.

Gratitude journals, forced smiles, and strategic avoidance

The standard advice for dealing with negativity bias falls into three categories, and all three make the problem worse if you follow them literally.

Fix one: Ignore negative information.

The logic here is that if your brain overweights bad news, you should consciously underweight it. Treat criticism as noise and focus on the positive. This works until you encounter negative information that actually matters. Your bank account is overdrawn, your project is behind schedule, or a relationship is deteriorating. Ignoring real problems because you’ve trained yourself to dismiss negative signals is how small issues become catastrophic ones. We’ve all been there, ignored a small issue that spiraled into a total disaster, we still think about years later.

我的第一辆车是现代Getz，当时我真的很喜欢它，尽管朋友们会拿这个品牌开玩笑。多年来我一直对这个品牌保持忠诚。有一天，"检查引擎"指示灯亮了，但车似乎没什么问题。我告诉自己可能只是传感器故障。我选择忽略这个警告，只关注它运行得有多好。几周后，我因为发动机过热被困在高速公路边。一个简单的修理变成了昂贵的大修。那天我学到，保持积极固然好，但忽视明确的警告信号可能导致更大的问题。有些问题永远不会消失，无论你的心态有多积极。那时我还学到，我真的需要更了解自己开的车。 第二个误区：强行积极。感恩日记、肯定语、刻意将每次挫折重新定义为学习机会。关于这方面的研究最多只能说是好坏参半。有些研究显示感恩练习有益处，但往往效果微小且会消退。2023年的一项荟萃分析发现，感恩干预对积极幸福感的效应值约为0.22，有意义但并非变革性的。在最初抑郁的人群中效果往往更大，而在试图提升基线幸福感的健康人群中效果较小。更重要的是，强行积极会产生第二个问题。如果你试图感到感恩却做不到，你现在就有两个问题：最初的负面事件，以及你未能正确认识自身处境。最终，你会因为感觉糟糕而感觉更糟。 第三个误区：麻木逃避。完全减少接触负面信息。退出社交媒体，停止看新闻。理想情况下，避免任何可能发生的困难对话。这在短期内有效。你的环境焦虑会下降。

One day, the “check engine” light came on, but the car seemed fine. I told myself it was probably just a faulty sensor. I chose to ignore the warning and focused on how well it was running. A few weeks later, I was stranded on the side of the highway with an overheated engine. A simple fix had turned into a major, expensive repair. That day taught me that while staying positive is good, ignoring clear warning signs can lead to much bigger problems. Some problems will never go away, no matter how positive your mindset is.

Another thing I learned back then was that I really need to know more about the cars I’m driving.

Fix two: Force positivity.

Gratitude journals, affirmations, and deliberate reframing of every setback as a learning opportunity. The research on this is mixed at best. Some studies show benefits from gratitude practices, but they tend to be small and they fade. A 2023 meta-analysis found that gratitude interventions produced effect sizes around 0.22 for positive well-being, meaningful but not transformative. The effects tend to be larger in populations that were initially depressed, smaller in healthy populations trying to boost baseline happiness.

More importantly, forced positivity creates a secondary problem. If you’re trying to feel grateful and you don’t, you now have two problems: the original negative event and your failure to properly appreciate your circumstances. At the end, you feel bad about feeling bad.

Fix three: Numb out.

Reduce exposure to negative information entirely. Quit social media, stop watching the news. Ideally, avoid any difficult conversations you might have. This works in the short term. Your ambient anxiety drops.

但你并没有修复威胁探测系统，只是移除了触发器。移除刺激源不会让系统变得迟钝，反而会使其更敏感，有时甚至过度敏感。越是逃避某件事，它在你心中就越庞大。当你最终再次接触负面信息时，反应会比持续接触时更剧烈。 不是说这些方法完全无效。感恩练习对部分人确有帮助，我人生某些阶段也受益于此。减少末日刷屏对多数人利大于弊——以我个人经历而言，暂别脸书和Instagram后，焦虑减轻，情绪和专注力都明显改善。 但这些只是治标不治本。你的大脑正完美执行演化赋予的使命：优先识别威胁。关键不在于说服大脑停止工作，而在于如何赋予它真正有益的任务。 你的杏仁核还以为活在公元前8000年 这种原始神经回路与现代环境的错位，在心理学家称为"概率忽视"的现象中尤为明显。大脑不擅长校准风险——它将低概率高危害事件（空难、恐袭）看得比高概率低危害事件（车祸、不良饮食）更危险，过度关注鲜明而近期的威胁，却轻视抽象遥远的风险。 这在远古环境中完全合理。若你曾见过狮子，就必须永生铭记。基数概率无关紧要——你不需要知道狮子仅0.01%的几率攻击人类，只需牢记狮子危险且必须躲避。这是简单的生存本能。

I’m not saying these strategies never work. Gratitude practices can be helpful for some people, and there were times in my life when I’d say they worked for me. Reducing doomscrolling is probably net positive for most. I can tell you from experience, it really worked for me. When I took a break from Facebook and Insta, my anxiety went down, and my mood and focus got a lot better.

But they’re treating the symptoms, not the mechanism. Your brain is doing exactly what it evolved to do: prioritize threats. The question isn’t how to convince your brain to stop. The question is how to give it a task that actually helps.

Your amygdala still thinks you live in 8000 BCE

The mismatch between ancient wiring and modern environment shows up most clearly in what psychologists call “probability neglect.” Your brain is not good at calibrating risk. It treats low-probability, high-severity events (plane crashes, terrorism) as more dangerous than high-probability, low-severity events (car accidents, poor diet). It overweights vivid, recent threats and underweights abstract, distant ones.

This made sense in the ancestral environment. If you saw a lion once, you needed to remember it forever. The base rate didn’t matter; you didn’t need to know that lions only attacked humans in 0.01% of encounters. You needed to know that lions are dangerous and to avoid them. A simple survival instinct.

但在这个多数威胁都是概率性而非二元对立的世界里，这种认知方式会造成系统性误判。你会更担心陌生人带来的危险而非车祸，尽管孩子死于交通事故的概率要高得多；你会更忧虑恐怖主义而非心脏病；你会将市场波动视作比持续低回报更严重的威胁。 由于现代媒体以吸引流量而非传递真相为目标，你不断接收着那些鲜活、近期、高显性的威胁信息。算法不会告诉你"今天99.9%的地方平安无事"，而是推送飞机失事、大规模枪击和金融崩溃的新闻。你的杏仁核将每起事件都记录为世界正在恶化的证据，即便总体统计数据表明事实恰恰相反。 这种认知偏差同样适用于个人威胁。你会更清晰地记住批评过你的人，而非十个没有批评你的人；更难忘未获得的工作机会，而非已到手的工作；更深刻铭记糟糕收场的关系，而非那些平静美好的岁月。 你的大脑正在用例外事件而非基础概率构建威胁模型，并以此指导行为。 这种认知方式会形成恐惧自我实现的闭环。消极偏见不仅会放大负面感受，更会形成制造更多负面事件的恶性循环。 当你在工作中收到批评反馈时，大脑会立即将其标记为威胁。威胁反应会窄化你的注意力——你开始更密切地监控上司的举动，寻找不满的迹象。而一旦你预设了寻找目标，确认偏误便开始运作，你总能找到"证据"。这种高度警觉让你更加焦虑，焦虑又影响工作表现，表现下滑招致更多批评，如此循环不断收紧。

And because modern media is optimized for engagement, not accuracy, you’re constantly being fed the vivid, recent, high-salience threats. The algorithm doesn’t show you “nothing happened today in 99.9% of places.” It shows you the plane crash, the mass shooting, and the financial collapse. Your amygdala catalogs each one as evidence that the world is getting more dangerous, even when aggregate statistics show the opposite.

There’s a version of this that applies to personal threats, too. You remember the person who criticized you more vividly than the ten people who didn’t. You remember the job you didn’t get more than the ones you did. You remember the relationship that ended badly more than the quiet years when things were fine.

Your brain is building a threat model from exceptions, not base rates. And then using that model to guide your behavior.

The feedback loop that creates what it fears

Negativity bias doesn’t just make bad things feel worse. It creates feedback loops that generate more bad things to feel bad about.

You get critical feedback at work, and your brain flags this immediately as a threat. Threat responses narrow your focus. You start monitoring your boss’s behavior more closely. Looking for signs of disapproval. And of course you find them, because confirmation bias kicks in once you’ve decided what you’re looking for. Your increased vigilance makes you more anxious. The anxiety affects your performance. Your performance drops, you get more critical feedback. The loop tightens.

或者，你看到关于经济的负面新闻。你的大脑将其归类为对财务安全的威胁。你开始更频繁地查看投资组合。频繁查看让你暴露于更多波动，从而加剧焦虑。焦虑让你更可能在市场低迷时抛售。低迷时抛售则锁定了亏损。亏损又印证了最初的威胁判断。于是你查看得更频繁。 这种模式在人际关系中同样存在。你将伴侣的心不在焉解读为他们对你生气的证据。你选择疏离或变得防备。对方察觉到你的行为变化，真的开始生气。你最初的解读由此得到验证，但这仅仅是因为你先采取了行动。 我不认为这种模式是普遍存在的。有些人似乎不易陷入这种恶性循环，我无法确定这是因为他们的负面偏见基线较低，还是因为他们建立了更好的"断路器"，或是他们的DNA不同，又或是他们所处的环境不易激活这种偏见。也许他们受到了父母或祖辈的影响，但这只是猜测。然而一旦这种循环形成，它就会自我强化。 现代环境中充满了旨在激活这种偏见的系统。绩效管理体系关注差距而非优势。 社交媒体平台突出冲突和任何能引发情绪的内容。新闻周期优先报道威胁，金融体系鼓励持续监控。每一股力量都在拉扯同一根进化形成的神经。 建立抗衡力量，而非对抗偏见 真正有效的解决方法不是减少负面输入或增加正面输入，而是为已经存在的偏见建立一个有意识的抗衡力量。 你的大脑会自动放大负面信息。你无法阻止这一点，但可以建立一个并行机制，有意识地放大正面信息，且不显得刻意或虚假。

The pattern shows up in relationships too. You interpret your partner’s distraction as evidence they’re upset with you. You withdraw or become defensive. They notice the shift in your behavior and actually become upset. Your original interpretation is now validated, but only because you acted on it first.

I’m not convinced this pattern is universal. There are people who seem less prone to these spirals, and I can’t tell if that’s because their baseline negativity bias is lower, because they’ve developed better circuit breakers, because their DNA is different, or because they’re in environments that don’t activate the bias as strongly. Maybe they were influenced by their parents or grandparents, but that’s just a guess. But in the cases where the loop does form, it’s self-reinforcing.

And the modern environment is full of systems designed to activate it. Performance management systems that focus on gaps rather than strengths.

Social media platforms that surface conflict and anything that creates emotion. News cycles that prioritize threats, financial systems that encourage constant monitoring. Each one is tugging on the same evolutionary wire.

Building a counterweight, not fighting the bias

The fix that actually works isn’t about reducing negative input or increasing positive input. It’s about building a deliberate counterweight to the bias that’s already running.

Your brain automatically amplifies negative information. You can’t stop that, but you can build a parallel process that deliberately amplifies positive information in a way that doesn’t feel forced or fake.

这与感恩日记不同。感恩日记要求你留意美好事物。这很好，但留意不等于放大。你的大脑已经注意到了那些好事，只是没有将它们存入长期记忆，因为它们不构成威胁。 真正有效的是建立仪式，迫使你对积极事件进行细节延伸。细节延伸才能创造深刻记忆。当好事发生时，大脑的默认模式是短暂留意后便转移注意力。干预的关键在于打断这个过程，让自己进行细节延伸： 具体发生了什么？感受如何？这反映了行为者怎样的特质？这对未来的互动预示着什么？ 谢尔顿和柳博米尔斯基在2006年的研究证实了这一点。他们追踪了进行各类积极心理学干预的人群，发现只有当人们变换记录时间并对细节进行延伸时，干预才有效果。机械重复"我感恩X"没有持续效果，而详细延伸"X为何重要及其意义"则能产生适度而持久的影响。 机制很重要。当你延伸积极事件时，并非自我欺骗或强行乐观，而是在修正记忆存储系统的已知偏差。大脑会自动以高细节、高显著度存储负面事件，你只是手动对积极事件进行同样的处理。 实践中是这样的：有人称赞你的工作→默认反应：短暂愉悦后继续工作→干预：暂停。对方具体称赞了什么？你付出了哪些可能被注意到的努力？他们的关注暗示了对你工作更广泛的看法？花60秒思考这些。

What works is building rituals that force elaboration on positive events. Elaboration is what creates strong memories. When something good happens, your brain’s default is to notice it briefly and move on. The intervention is to interrupt that process and make yourself elaborate: What specifically happened? What did it feel like? What does it suggest about the person who did it? What might it predict about future interactions?

There’s research on this from 2006 by Sheldon and Lyubomirsky. They tracked people doing various positive psychology interventions and found that the interventions only worked when people varied the timing and elaborated on the details. Rote repetition of “I’m grateful for X” showed no sustained effect. Detailed elaboration on why X mattered and what it meant showed modest but persistent effects.

The mechanism matters. When you elaborate on a positive event, you’re not lying to yourself or forcing optimism. You’re correcting for a known bias in your storage system. Your brain stored the negative event automatically with high detail and high salience. You’re manually doing the same thing for the positive event.

In practice, this looks like this: Someone compliments your work → Default response: brief pleasure, then move on. → Intervention: Stop. What specifically did they compliment? What effort did you put in that they might have noticed? What does their noticing suggest about how they view your work more broadly? Spend 60 seconds on this.

或者，一个项目进展顺利。→ 默认反应：松一口气，感到满意，转向下一个项目。→ 干预措施：具体哪些方面进展顺利？哪些决策促成了这个结果？这说明了你在该领域具备怎样的能力？请像分析失败案例那样，用同等程度的细节来记录这些成功经验。 这并非关乎自尊，而是为了构建一个准确的威胁评估模型。如果你的大脑只详细记录失败，而对成功仅存模糊印象，那么你对自己能力的认知就会出现偏差。你会系统性地低估自己能应对的情况，同时高估所面临的风险。 这种干预之所以有效，是因为它契合了大脑的实际运作方式。你不是在与消极偏见作斗争，而是在并行建立一个与之对等的积极处理机制。 它能消除焦虑吗？不能。它应该消除焦虑吗？我不确定。一定程度的威胁警觉可能是有适应性的。目标并非时刻保持愉悦，而是建立一个反映现实而非进化历史的威胁评估模型。 坦率地说，要做到这一点相当困难，因为我们的大脑仍以为我们正被猛兽追赶，它只是在努力帮助我们生存下去。 好的想法是通过人与人之间传播，而非算法。如果你认识可能对此感兴趣的人，请分享。 分享 当放大仪式本身成为问题 我反复观察到四种模式，在这些情况下常规建议会失效，这也提示了我们何时应该、何时不应该尝试纠正偏见。 多年来，我听到的关于管理消极偏见的建议大多将其视为一个具有通用解决方案的普遍问题。 但有些情况下，你的威胁检测系统提供的是准确信息，此时试图放大积极信号只会增加干扰： 阅读更多

This isn’t about self-esteem. It’s about building an accurate threat model. If your brain only stores failures in high detail and successes in low detail, your model of your own capability is wrong. You’ll systematically underestimate what you can handle and overestimate the risks you face.

The intervention works because it matches the way your brain actually operates. You’re not fighting negativity bias. You’re building an equal and opposite process that runs in parallel.

Does it eliminate anxiety? No. Should it? I’m not sure. Some level of threat vigilance is probably adaptive. The goal isn’t to feel good all the time, the goal is to have a threat model that reflects reality instead of evolutionary history.

And let's face it, that is quite hard to do because our brain still thinks that we are chased by predators, so it’s just trying to help us survive.

Good ideas spread through people, not algorithms. Share if you know someone who’d enjoy this.

Share

When the amplification ritual becomes the problem

There are four patterns I’ve seen repeatedly where the standard advice breaks down, and what that suggests about when you should and shouldn’t try to correct for bias.

Most of the advice I’ve heard over the years on managing negativity bias treats it as a universal problem with a universal solution.

But there are situations where your threat detection system is giving you accurate information, and trying to amplify positive signals just adds noise:

item.title: 当每条信息都完美无缺，便没有信息真正重要。
item.description:
几个月前，朋友雅娜给我看了她的领英收件箱。当时我们坐在瓦茨拉夫广场（如果你不是捷克人，它在布拉格）附近的咖啡馆，窗外下着雨，她刚抱怨完浓缩咖啡太苦。她滑动屏幕翻看大约三十条消息，每条都提及她近期关于候选人"已读不回"的帖子，每条都精准称呼她的名字和公司。 好几条消息还提到她资料中的具体细节、公司最近的融资情况，甚至包括她两周前在某会议发言的事实。每条都在用高度个性化的邮件推销招聘服务。"五年前这种邮件或许能打动我，"她说。现在她批量删除这些消息，从不会读完第一行之后的内容。 因为她知道。所有人都知道这些邮件写得太好，好得过分，而且数量惊人——它们由工具生成，能抓取个人资料、分析发帖规律，炮制出看似真人花十分钟研读她作品后写出的内容。最疯狂的不是这些邮件像垃圾信息，而是它们大多不像，且都能顺利通过她公司和Gmail的过滤器。 大多数建议千篇一律，但这里不同。订阅我们，收获引发思考的洞见。 收件箱看似正常，直到它不再正常 转变发生在2024年末的某个时刻，虽然我询问过的人都说不清具体月份。消息开始变得更精妙——不是那种沿用多年的"嗨{姓名}，关注到贵公司"的模板化操作，而是真正意义上的优化：引用具体帖子、使用自然语言、提出相关见解、包含体现发送者真实调研时间的细节。Wenceslas Square (if you are not from the Czech Republic, it's located in Prague), it was raining, and she’d just finished complaining about the espresso being too bitter. She scrolled through maybe thirty messages. Every single one referenced her recent post about candidate ghosting. Everyone used her first name and company name as well.

Several mentioned specific details from her profile, her company’s recent investment, and the fact that she’d spoken at a conference two weeks earlier.

Every single one of them was trying to pitch their recruitment agency services with a hyper-personalized email.

“Five years ago, this would’ve meant something,” she said.

Now she deletes them in batches without reading past the first line. Because she knows. They all know the messages are good, too good, and far too many. Written by tools that can scrape a profile, analyze posting patterns, and generate something that sounds like it came from a human who actually read her work and thought about it for ten minutes.

The crazy part isn’t that the messages are obvious spam. It’s that most of them aren’t, and they all pass her company and Gmail filters without any problems.

Most advice sounds the same. This won’t. Subscribe for ideas that make you think.

Inbox looked normal until it wasn’t

The shift happened sometime in late 2024, though nobody I’ve talked to can pin down an exact month. Messages started getting better. Not in the “Hey {FirstName}, I noticed your company” obvious mail-merge way we knew for years, but they actually got better. They referenced specific posts, used natural language, made relevant observations, and included details that suggested the sender had spent real time on research.

贾娜说，起初收到这类消息时还挺受用。一家供应商公司的员工给她发信息，提到她之前做的一次演讲，具体指出了她使用的某个框架，还提了一个很有见地的后续问题。她回复了这些消息，以为对方是真人。他们甚至有过不错的交流。 后来她发现，同一个人给她认识的另外六位招聘人员发了几乎一模一样的"个性化"信息。结构相同，只是替换了不同的细节。那是个周二的下午，她记得很清楚，因为下午三点她有个候选人面试，差点因为被这件事惹恼而错过。 邮件数量开始激增。每周十条个性化信息变成了三十条，然后是五十条，不仅发到她的公司邮箱，还发到领英，后来连她的WhatsApp也开始收到。这一切都拜人工智能和多渠道触达所赐。如果有什么是我个人不喜欢的，那就是这个。 她甚至开始收到发到她个人手机号码的短信，而这个号码她一直很注意不公开。每条信息都有足够的背景信息，让人感觉是真实的。并非所有信息都在明显推销。有些只是……对话。试图建立联系，人们"联系她"是因为他们"一直在关注她的工作"。 她不再回复任何感觉过于流畅的信息。如果一条信息没有错别字，语法完美，并且击中了关系建立手册中的每一个心理触发点，它就会被扔进垃圾箱。 讽刺的是，现在她可能会删除那些恰好文笔很好的真人发来的真实信息。但账已经算不过来了。当你回复一条信息需要花费五到十分钟（如果你不使用人工智能的话），而其中真正是人类的概率可能只有二十分之一时，你就会停止参与这场游戏。 虚假亲密的经济学。

Then she noticed the same person had sent near-identical “personalized” messages to six other recruiters she knew. Same structure, different details swapped in. It was a Tuesday afternoon, she remembers that because she had a candidate interview at 3pm that she almost missed because she was too annoyed by the realization.

The email volume accelerated. Ten personalized messages a week became thirty. Then fifty, often sent not only to her company email but also to her LinkedIn, and then her WhatsApp started getting them too. All thanks to AI and multichannel outreach. If there is one thing I personally do not like, it is this.

She started getting text messages even on her personal phone number, which she’s pretty careful not to share publicly. Each one had enough context to feel legitimate. Not all of them were selling something obvious. Some were just... conversations. Networking attempts, people “reaching out” because they’d “been following her work.”

She stopped responding to anything that felt too smooth. If a message had zero typos, perfect grammar, and hit every psychological trigger in the relationship-building playbook, it went to trash.

The irony is that now she probably deletes real messages from real people who just happen to write well. But the math doesn’t work anymore. When responding to one message costs five to ten minutes (if you are not using AI), and the hit rate on genuine humans is maybe one in twenty, you stop playing.

The economics of fake intimacy

个性化曾经是件奢侈的事。写一封出色的陌生邮件需要调研、时间，以及相应的技巧。你得研读对方作品，理解其背景，寻找真诚的连接点。这很耗时，而时间就是金钱。因此个性化只留给高价值目标。当你收到真正个性化的信息时，它意味着对方投入了稀缺资源专门为你而来。 人工智能让这种投入变得免费——或者说近乎免费到可以忽略不计。如今你生成一百封个性化邮件的时间，过去只够写一封。每封邮件都能引用具体细节，模仿沟通风格，适配收件人所在行业，且除初始设置外无需人工干预。 不过有项有趣的研究与此相关，虽然并非专门针对AI生成的外联信息。 宾夕法尼亚大学的保罗·罗津在1980年代研究了他称之为"传染效应"的现象，观察人们如何评估物品价值。名人穿过的毛衣比同款未穿过的更值钱。但若告知对方名人毛衣被完美复制，其价值便骤然崩塌。并非因为质量改变，而是稀缺性消失了。 同样的机制正在瓦解个性化。当人人都能生成看似手工打造的信息时，手工制作便失去价值。信号开始失真。一封深思熟虑的邮件过去意味着"此人足够重视我，愿投入二十分钟专注努力"，现在却意味着"这人能用ChatGPT和领英数据抓取工具"。 销售和招聘领域已被这种信息洪流淹没。其他渠道也将陆续沦陷：筹款、政治竞选，尤其是诈骗领域。它甚至将渗透到熟人间的私人交流——既然能用AI帮你构思更得体的道歉、更清晰的解释、更周到的感谢信，何乐而不为呢？

AI makes that investment free. Or close enough to free that it rounds to zero. You can now generate a hundred personalized messages in the time it used to take to write one. Each message can reference specific details, mirror communication styles, adapt to the recipient’s industry, and do it all without human intervention past the initial setup.

There’s interesting research on this, though not specifically about AI-generated outreach. Paul Rozin at Penn studied something he called “contagion” in the 1980s, looking at how people value objects. A sweater worn by a celebrity is worth more than an identical unworn one. But if you tell someone the celebrity sweater was duplicated perfectly, the value collapses. Not because the quality changed. Because scarcity did.

The same mechanism breaks personalization. When everyone can generate messages that look hand-crafted, the hand-crafting loses value. The signal degrades. A thoughtful email used to mean “this person cares enough about reaching me to invest twenty minutes of focused effort.” Now it means “this person has access to ChatGPT and a LinkedIn scraper.”

The flood is already here in sales and recruiting. It’s coming for every other channel. Fundraising, political campaigns, and especially in scams. It's even coming for personal communication between people who actually know each other, because why wouldn’t you use AI to help craft a better apology, a clearer explanation, a more thoughtful thank-you note?

我不太确定“用工具更好地沟通”和“自动化沟通到不再属于你”之间的界限在哪里。我怀疑这条界限比我们想象的要模糊得多，而且我们可能会反复跨越而不自知，直到伤害累积。 当有人在领英上联系你，说他们欣赏你的作品，但你能看出他们甚至没访问过你的个人资料，而且信息是由领英AI生成的，这种感觉有点奇怪。你会怎么做？你会用AI生成的信息回复，或者至少用AI来修正语法。 在整个过程中，人的参与部分非常小。我们只需要点击“生成”来创建内容，然后点击“发送”来分享它。 伪造的声音和克隆的面孔不再是边缘案例了。 两个月前，我的朋友彼得接到母亲的电话。她在哭。她说急需用钱；出了事故，电话里说不清楚，让他立刻往一个账户转2000欧元。他差点照做了，因为声音太逼真了；他告诉我，那哭声听起来很真实。 他回拨同一个号码确认账户信息。母亲接起电话说她很好，正在家看电视。完全不知道他在说什么。有人克隆了她的声音，很可能来自几年前她发布在脸书上的一段视频。 这不再是理论上的事了。声音克隆工具已经广泛可用； ElevenLabs 以及其他许多工具都能在几分钟内完成，有时甚至只需几秒。视频深度伪造越来越难辨别。伪造视频通话的技术已经存在，而且每月都在变得更便宜。我读到过一个案例， 香港一名金融工作者在参加了一场深度伪造的视频会议后，向诈骗者转账2500万美元 视频中的人看起来和公司的首席财务官及其他高管一模一样。那是2024年2月的事；如果你现在查看Kling或Seedance的新版本，这些工具已经先进得多了。

It feels a bit weird when someone reaches out on LinkedIn saying they admire your work, but you can tell they haven’t even visited your profile, and the message is AI-generated, thanks to LinkedIn AI. And what do you do? You reply with a message also generated by AI, or at least use AI to fix the grammar.

Throughout this whole process, the human part was pretty small. All we had to do was click “generate” to create the content and then “send” to share it.

Spoofed voices and cloned faces aren’t edge cases anymore

My friend Petr’s mother called him two months ago. She was crying. She said she needed money immediately; there'd been an accident, she couldn't explain on the phone, and asked him to send 2,000 euros to this account number right now. He was about to do it, because the voice was perfect; he told me that the crying sounded real.

He called her back on the same number to confirm the account. She answered that she was fine, just watching television at home. Had no idea what he was talking about. Someone had cloned her voice, probably from a video she’d posted to Facebook a few years ago.

This isn’t theoretical anymore. Voice cloning tools are widely available; ElevenLabs and many others can do that within minutes, sometimes in seconds. Video deepfakes are getting harder to spot. The technology to spoof a video call exists and is getting cheaper every month. I read about a case in Hong Kong where a finance worker transferred $25 million after a deepfaked video conference call with people who looked exactly like the company’s CFO and other executives. That was February 2024; if you check new versions of Kling or Seedance, these tools are way better now.

当基本假设从“如果我听到某人的声音，那很可能就是本人”转变为“未经二次验证，我无法信任任何音频或视频”时会发生什么？我们尚未形成相应的文化规范。我们仍在使用前人工智能时代的威胁模型，那时复杂的攻击还罕见得足以成为新闻。 莱德大学的心理学教授约翰·苏勒曾提出导致人们在线上与线下行为差异的六个因素。匿名性是其一，但隐形性、异步性以及他所谓的“解离想象”——即认为线上互动并不完全真实——同样关键。那是2004年。现在再加上完美的声音模仿、以假乱真的视频，以及能够实时对话、几乎零延迟地伪装成你信任之人的AI。 问题不在于这会否被恶意利用——恶意利用已然发生，而在于文化免疫系统的适应速度。我常想，这究竟是否可能。 当万物皆可模拟，真实感从何而来？我们依赖数十种细微信号判断真实性：音色质感、措辞习惯、回应延迟。某人组织解释的方式，特定位置出现的拼写错误（尽管AI现已能修正所有文本），还有那些外人难以伪造的共享语境指涉。 如今所有这些信号都能被模仿。虽未臻完美，但已足以在多数时候欺骗大多数人。而误差率每几个月就会下降。看看Instagram或TikTok视频：几个月前你还能立刻识别AI生成内容，现在却会迟疑——这人究竟是真实存在还是又一个AI？ 当真实性可被完美伪造，信任便从内容转向元数据。重要的不再是言语本身，而是表达方式及经过验证的传播渠道。双因素认证、蓝V标识、验证徽章已显现这种趋势。但这些系统同样会被攻破。验证本身正在成为新的攻击面。if I hear someone’s voice, it’s probably them” to “I can’t trust audio or video without secondary verification”? We don’t have cultural norms for that yet. We’re still operating on pre-AI threat models where sophisticated attacks were rare enough to be newsworthy.

A professor of Psychology at Rider University, John Suler, identified six factors that make people behave differently online versus in person. Anonymity was one, but so were invisibility, asynchronicity, and what he called “dissociative imagination1,” the sense that online interactions aren’t quite real. That was 2004. Now add perfect voice mimicry, video that looks real, and AI that can hold a conversation in real-time with almost no latency, while pretending to be someone you trust.

The question isn’t whether this will be used maliciously. It already is, but the question is how fast the cultural immune system adapts. I often wonder, if its even possible.

What makes something feel real when everything can be simulated

We rely on dozens of small signals to determine authenticity: voice timbre, word choice, and response latency. The way someone structures an explanation, typos in predictable places, even though AI is now able to fix any text. References to shared context that would be hard for an outsider to fake.

All of those signals can be mimicked now. Not perfectly, not yet, but well enough to fool most people most of the time. And the error rate drops every few months. Just take Instagram or TikTok videos, a few months ago you would spot an AI video immediately, now you wonder, is that person real or another AI?

When authenticity can be faked perfectly, trust shifts from content to metadata. Not what someone says, but how they say it and through what verified channel. We’re already seeing this with two-factor authentication, blue checkmarks, verified badges. But those systems break too. Verification becomes a new attack surface.

或许存在一种去中心化身份系统能解决这个问题的方案。加密签名、信任网络模型。但我对这些技术相当怀疑——并非因为技术本身不可行，而是因为推广需要改变数十亿人的行为习惯，而安全威胁在亲身遭遇前总是隐形的。大多数人总要等到吃亏后才开始采取防护措施，那时损失已经造成了。 我始终震惊于竟有如此多人连邮箱双重验证都不设置，除非邮箱服务商强制要求。 安全词、验证码…… 最近开始听说有些家庭开始设立口头密码。我在伦敦的朋友爱丽丝告诉我，她父母在读到语音克隆诈骗的报道后，决定设置一个暗语。现在家里任何人打电话要钱或声称有急事，都必须先说出这个暗语。她说这种感觉既像被迫害妄想，又完全合乎情理，真是种奇特的组合。 企业也在测试类似系统。有些公司开始对涉及资金转移的请求实施二次验证，即使邮件来自已知的内部邮箱。要求用已验证号码回拨，或通过其他渠道确认。 代价是时间和麻烦。每个验证步骤都会拖慢正常沟通。如果你的工作需要快速决策，给每个重要对话增加三层验证，可能意味着成交生意与错失良机的区别。但不增加这些防护，又可能因为落入事后看来显而易见的骗局，面临保住工作与被解雇的差别。或许我过于谨慎了，但这确实是我们面临的现实。 我认为我们尚未找到平衡点。大多数人仍处于因威胁过于抽象或仅存在于网络报道中，而完全不采取防护措施的阶段。

I am always shocked by how many people do not even have 2FA for their emails, unless their email provider forces them to use it.

Safe words, verification codes, and…

I’ve started hearing about families creating verbal passwords. My friend Alice, who lives in London, told me that her parents decided on a code phrase after reading about voice-cloning scams. If anyone in the family calls asking for money or claiming there’s an emergency, they have to use the phrase first. She said it feels paranoid and also completely reasonable, which is a weird combination.

Companies are testing similar systems. Some are implementing secondary verification for any request involving financial transfers, even if it comes from a known internal email address. Call back on a verified number, confirm via a different channel.

The cost is time and annoyance. Every verification step slows down legitimate communication. If you’re in a role where fast decisions matter, adding three verification layers to every high-stakes conversation could be the difference between closing a deal and losing it. But not adding those layers could be the difference between keeping your job and getting fired for falling for a scam that should’ve been obvious in retrospect. Perhaps I’m being overly cautious, but this is the reality we’re facing.

I don’t think we’ve figured out the right tradeoff yet. We’re still in the phase where most people don’t implement any protection because the threat feels abstract or something you are reading about on the internet.

当身边有人首次遭遇攻击时，情况就变了。钟摆会猛地荡向另一个极端——所有系统都被严密封锁，工作效率一落千丈。最终我们总能找到折中方案，但过渡期总会经历混乱。 另一个问题在于认证系统天然具有排他性。若要求所有通讯都经过加密验证，就等于将那些缺乏技术能力的人隔绝在外。我的朋友们都用WhatsApp，我正竭力避开这个"数字瘟疫"，但说服他们改用 Signal 简直难如登天。 安全层反而成了人际连接的壁垒，对年长亲属尤其如此。或许这是值得付出的代价？我也说不准。 瑕疵即真实 我注意到一个奇特现象：如今最可信的信息往往带着瑕疵。不是那种明显的垃圾信息特征，而是人类特有的小毛病——自动纠错没捕捉到的拼写错误，略显散漫的句子结构，因忙于无关事务而延迟三天回复的歉意。 上周有位客户发来消息开头写着："抱歉刚看到，孩子学校有点事，之后一直忘了查邮件直到现在。"这听起来很真实。AI不会忘记查邮件，AI没有要参加校园活动的孩子。AI要么秒回，要么经过精密计算后假装忙碌延迟回复，但绝不会用这种毫无策略价值的日常琐事来解释延迟。 我明白这种状况只是暂时的，AI终将学会植入策略性瑕疵。现在通过特定指令也能实现，但至少在我看来仍欠真实。下一代工具会在统计学的恰当位置插入刻意拼写错误，添加随机延迟，为慢回复编造合理借口。不过我们尚未抵达那个阶段（至少我认为没有），在当下与未来的间隙里，那些粗糙之处反而成了真实性的微弱信号。

The other problem is that authentication systems create exclusion. If you require cryptographic verification for all communication, you’ve just cut off anyone who doesn’t have the technical literacy to set that up. All my friends use WhatsApp, I am trying to avoid it as it's a plague, but getting them to Signal is almost impossible.

The security layer becomes a barrier to connection, especially for elderly relatives. Maybe that’s an acceptable tradeoff, I’m not sure.

Friction as a signal

There is something strange I keep noticing. The most credible messages I get now are the ones with mistakes. Not obvious spam mistakes, but human ones. Typos that autocorrect didn’t catch, sentences that wander. An apology for taking three days to respond because they got busy with something unrelated.

A client sent me a message last week that started with “Sorry, just saw this, my kid had a thing at school and then I forgot to check email until now.” That sounds real. AI doesn’t forget to check email. AI doesn’t have kids with school events. AI would generate a response within seconds or wait a calculated amount of time to simulate busyness, but it wouldn’t explain the delay with a specific mundane excuse that adds no strategic value to the message.

I realize this is temporary, eventually AI will learn to add strategic imperfection. You can do it now with the right prompting, but it still does not feel real, at least to me. The next generation of tools will insert deliberate typos in statistically appropriate places. Add random delays, generate plausible excuses for slow responses. But we’re not there yet (at least I don't think we are), and in the gap between now and then, sloppiness becomes a weak signal of authenticity.

长期来看，均衡状态很可能不是"不完美即真实"——这种标准太容易被钻空子。更可能出现的情况是，认证与伪造之间将展开军备竞赛，验证成本随时间不断攀升，最终多数沟通只能通过需要身份验证的封闭渠道进行。 电子邮件和私信将变得不可用。或许我们会退回到小型验证网络，就像脸书或领英那样，但仅限于真正相识的人——在那里每个人都彼此认识，陌生人没有引荐无法加入。 这种模式也有代价，网络效应至关重要。开放通信曾催生许多有价值的事物：弱连接将不同社群联系起来，素未谋面者的偶然接触可能带来意外机遇。关闭这些通道，我们将失去真实存在的东西。 我对此没有完美答案。信息洪流已经形成且将愈演愈烈。现有解决方案大多要么难以规模化，要么引发新问题。我们或许只能勉强应对：结合验证系统、行为适应，并无奈接受部分通信已成为必须过滤的噪音。 我确切知道的是，曾经珍视的个性化沟通价值——那种对方花时间了解我是谁、在乎什么的感觉——已不复存在。信号质量恶化到我无法再信任的程度。个性化不再意味着稀缺性，相关工具已然存在，人们必将使用它们。 如今一切都像是数字游戏。我仍记得招聘专员认真撰写个性化邮件的时代，而现在？几分钟内就能触达五千人，只需点击按钮，随意添加收件人。

Email becomes unusable, direct messages become unusable. Maybe we all retreat to small, verified networks where everyone knows everyone else and strangers can’t get in without a referral, something like Facebook or LinkedIn, but for people we really know.

That has costs too, network effects matter. Open communication enabled a lot of valuable things. Weak ties connect disparate communities. Serendipitous connections happen because someone you don’t know can reach you. Close all that down and you lose something real.

I don’t have a clean answer here. The flood is already happening and it’s going to get worse. Most of the proposed solutions either don’t scale or create new problems. We’ll probably muddle through with some combination of verification systems, behavioral adaptation, and resigned acceptance that a certain percentage of communication is now just noise you have to filter.

What I do know is that the thing I used to value about personalized outreach, the sense that someone had invested time in understanding who I was and what I cared about, doesn’t work anymore. The signal is degraded past the point where I can trust it. And I don’t think we’re going back to a world where personalization means scarcity. The tools exist, and people will use them.

Everything these days also feels like a numbers game. I still remember the time when recruiters spent time writing personalized emails, and now? It’s easy to reach 5,000 people in minutes; the only thing you need to do is hit one button and add as many recipients as you’d like.

或许五年后，我们会形成新的文化规范来应对这种局面。或许我们会笑着回忆曾经竟把邮箱和电话号码当作身份凭证。又或许我们会陷入某种僵局——每场对话都需要繁复验证，最终只与熟人往来，而与陌生人建立信任的成本将高昂到令人却步。 我依然会查看信息，也会回复其中一部分。但判断信息可信度、决定是否值得关注的门槛正不断抬高，我或许因此错过了真正的机会——只因无法将其与算法生成的噪音区分开来。 好的思想通过人而非算法传播。若你身边有人会喜欢这篇文章，不妨分享给他们。 值得一读的文章： 1 解离性想象指的是一种精神状态：个体通过高度专注，从当下环境中抽离，沉浸于生动而逼真的幻想或平行现实中。

I still check my messages. I still respond to some of them. But the bar keeps rising for what counts as credible enough to warrant attention, and I’m probably missing real opportunities because I can’t tell them apart from generated noise.

item.title: 发货速度加快，但学到的东西比想象中少
item.description:
几个月前，我目睹一位朋友用一个周末做出个浏览器小工具。成品能用，界面清爽，没出bug，甚至还有包含完整信息的README文档。 周一，一个小地方坏了。刷新后某个按钮无法保存设置。不算大问题，但很烦人。 我们紧急开了个线上会议。夜深了，有人麦克风蹭着帽衫抽绳沙沙作响，我正嚼着乏味的办公桌零食，指尖沾满盐粒。他调出代码开始滚动，像在只去过一次的城市里寻找似曾相识的路牌。 这工具几乎全是他用AI助手（Claude 4.5）完成的。 当bug出现时，他脑中根本没有地图。不是"我忘了具体哪行代码"，而是"我不知道这部分应该做什么"。他能描述界面，能描述功能，却解释不清运行逻辑。他无法预测状态存储在哪里，什么被缓存，页面加载时哪些环节会重新执行。 于是他做了现在大多数人会做的事——把报错信息粘贴给模型，等待修复方案。 模型建议修改。他照做，然后得到新报错。 再来一个建议。再打补丁，再出新错。现在工具依然不能用，代码还逐渐扭曲成我们都不认识的模样。 我在软件团队、分析团队、招聘团队待得够久，能认出这种状态。不是能力不足，不是懒惰，而是完全不同的东西——那种能交付成果却无法自我解释的特殊能力。 AI让你更快地产出成果。 同时也让你更容易跳过将工作转化为技能的过程。 人们往往察觉不到问题，因为一切看起来都很好——直到出问题为止。当你第一次需要在没有助手的情况下调试、扩展、教学、辩护或重建时，才会发现自己真正学到了什么。 在意识到之前就已失去 问题不在于AI"过于强大"，而在于它的强大改变了你的工作姿态。

On Monday, one tiny thing broke. A button stopped saving settings after a refresh. Nothing dramatic, just annoying.

We jumped on a call. It was late, someone’s microphone kept rubbing against a hoodie string, and I was eating the kind of sad desk snack that leaves salt on your fingers. He pulled up the code and started scrolling like he was looking for a familiar street sign in a city he’d visited once.

He built almost all of it with an AI assistant (Claude 4.5).

When the bug appeared, he had no mental map. Not “I forgot the exact line,” but “I don’t know what this part is supposed to do.” He could describe the UI. He could describe the feature. He couldn’t explain the flow. He couldn’t predict where state lived, or what got cached, or what re-ran when the page loaded.

So he did what most people do now. He pasted the error into the model and waited for a fix.

It suggested a change. He applied it, and he got a new error.

Another suggestion. Another patch, another new error. And now the tool still didn’t work, plus the code was drifting into a shape neither of us recognized.

I’ve been around software teams, analytics teams, and recruiting teams long enough to recognize it. Not incompetence, not laziness, but something else entirely. It’s that specific kind of competence that ships, but can’t explain itself.

AI makes you faster at producing outputs. It also makes it easier to skip the part that turns work into skill.

People don’t notice because everything looks fine until it doesn’t. The first time you need to debug, extend, teach, defend, or rebuild without the helper, you find out what you actually learned.

What You Lose Before You Realize It

The problem isn’t that AI is “too good.” The problem is that it’s good in a way that changes your posture.

从前，你写东西时大脑必须追踪因果逻辑。你在工作记忆中记住若干约束条件，尝试一个猜想，发现错了，感受到那种摩擦，然后调整。你一边写一边构建起一个混乱的内在模型。 如今工作流程变了。你输入提示，接收结果，快速浏览，接受或拒绝。角色悄然从"建造者"转变为"编辑者"。 这听起来不错，因为编辑仍像在思考。有时确实是，但往往不是。 关于人类依赖自动化辅助工具会发生什么，已有研究。 Parasuraman和Riley将其概括为自动化的误用与弃用，包括过度依赖和监控减少，这可能导致即使是有能力的操作者也会遗漏错误。 这部分常让人联想到飞机和医疗设备。同样的模式也出现在日常知识工作中，只是换上了不那么戏剧化的外衣。 你接受了并非自己生成的输出。 你不再检查那些曾经费力的部分。 你失去了察觉异常的能力。 多数建议千篇一律。这里不同。订阅能引发思考的观点。 更糟的是，人工智能表达流畅。它能生成自信的论述、看似合理的代码、整洁的摘要。流畅性会欺骗大脑。你觉得自己理解了，因为你认出了那些词语和结构。识别事物很容易，但从零开始回忆却很难。 而检索正是构建神经连接的关键步骤。 学习之所以能扎根，是因为强迫自己从大脑中提取信息会改变记忆。 Roediger和Karpicke的研究表明，与重复学习相比，参加测试能提高后续记忆保持率——即使没有反馈，尤其是在数日后而非数分钟后测量效果时。 这不是励志口号。这是一个反复验证的发现，在医学教育等应用场景中也得到证实：相比重复学习，反复测试更能提升长期记忆保持。

Now the workflow is different. You prompt. You receive. You skim. You accept or reject. The role quietly shifts from “builder” to “editor.”

That sounds fine, because editing still feels like thinking. Sometimes it is, often it isn’t.

There’s research on what happens when humans rely on automated aids. Parasuraman and Riley1 framed it as misuse and disuse of automation, including over-reliance and reduced monitoring, which can lead to errors being missed even by capable operators.

That’s the part most people associate with planes and medical devices. The same pattern shows up in everyday knowledge work, just in a less dramatic costume.

You accept output you didn’t generate.
You stop checking parts that used to be effortful.
You lose the ability to notice what’s off.

Most advice sounds the same. This won’t. Subscribe for ideas that make you think.

It gets worse, because AI is fluent. It produces confident prose, plausible code, tidy summaries. Fluency tricks the brain. You feel like you understood because you recognized the words and the structure. Recognizing something is easy, but recalling it from scratch is hard.

And retrieval is the expensive step that builds the wiring.

One reason learning sticks is that forcing yourself to pull information out of your head changes memory. Roediger and Karpicke2 showed that taking tests improves later retention, even without feedback, compared to repeated studying, especially when you measure days later rather than minutes later.

That’s not a motivational poster idea. It’s a finding that shows up again and again, including in applied settings like medical education, where repeated testing can improve long-term retention compared to restudying.

AI密集型工作流程消除了许多被迫检索的时刻。你无需回忆语法规则，不必费力构思结构，也不用自己生成解释——你只需评判最终输出。 但这里还有另一个令我隐隐不安的角度，因为这不仅关乎记忆，更关乎大脑对知识储存位置的预期。Sparrow、Liu和Wegner关于"谷歌效应"的研究发现，人们更容易记住信息的位置而非信息本身，且思考难题时会下意识联想到计算机。这并非简单的"网络有害论"，而是更具体的认知适应：当外部获取可靠时，大脑会相应减少内部存储的投入。你可以说这是理性的选择，但也不得不承认这会改变你的思维模式。 我注意到一个尚未能完全论证却反复出现的现象：年轻一代对缺乏基础知识表现出惊人的坦然。他们不以为耻，只是平静地认为"何必记在脑子里"。这或许无妨，甚至可能是健康的认知策略。但我们尚未真正理解，当"随时可查"成为包括思考必需素材在内的一切事物的默认设定时，究竟意味着什么。 这种改变往往不易察觉。简而言之：技能源于创造而非评判。当你亲自生成答案时，即使质量不佳，也能暴露认知缺口，获得即时纠错信号，并内化解决问题的路径——这条路径往往比最终答案更有价值。这就是经典的"生成效应"：相比被动接收，主动生成的信息更易被牢记。Slamecka和Graf早在1978年就通过系列实验证实了这一点。 当你用AI助手生成初稿、初步方案或基础解释时，实质跳过了生成环节。你获得了最终成果，却缺失了使其真正"属于你"的认知建构过程。

You don’t have to recall the syntax.
You don’t have to wrestle the structure.
You don’t have to generate the explanation.

You just judge the output.

There’s another angle here that makes me uneasy, because it’s not only about memory. It’s about where your brain expects knowledge to live.

Sparrow, Liu, and Wegner’s3 “Google effects on memory” paper found that people tend to remember where to find information rather than the information itself, and that thinking about hard questions can prime thinking about computers.

That’s not “internet bad.” It’s more specific: when external access is reliable, the brain adapts by shifting effort away from internal storage. You can argue that this is rational. You can also admit it changes you.

A quick digression that I can’t fully defend, except that I keep noticing it: I’m seeing younger people get surprisingly calm about not knowing basics. Not embarrassed, just calm. Like “why would I store that in my head.” Maybe it’s fine. Maybe it’s healthy. I don’t know. I just don’t think we’ve sat with what it means when the default is “I can fetch it” for everything, including the parts you used to need in order to think.

The Change You Don’t Feel Right Away

If you want the short explanation, it’s this: skill comes from producing, not approving.

When you generate an answer yourself, even a bad one, you expose gaps. You get immediate error signals. You also encode the path you took. That path is often more valuable than the final answer.

There’s a classic finding called the generation effect. People remember information better when they generate it themselves rather than just reading it. Slamecka and Graf4 demonstrated this across multiple experiments in 1978.

When you use an AI assistant for first drafts, first solutions, first explanations, you skip generation. You get the final product without the cognitive work that makes it “yours.”

表面看来你显得很能干。你能交付成果，能高谈阔论，甚至可能因为表达比你自己写的更清晰而显得更聪明。 直到你遇到需要内在模型支撑的时刻。 调试就是个好例子。你无法凭感觉调试，需要建立一套逻辑链条：本应发生什么、实际发生了什么、偏差可能出现在哪里。这种链条源于你过去构建过的类似推理。 人们总担心"幻觉"风险。这确实存在，但属于显性风险。更隐蔽的风险在于，你逐渐放弃了那些让你保持韧性的思考方式。 我并非鼓吹苦难浪漫主义。很多挣扎纯粹是浪费时间，我自己就浪费过不少。 我想说的是，存在一类具有建设性的摩擦，而人工智能默认将其消除了。 为何"顺畅"是危险信号 这很难接受：当你只关注产出时，学习过程若显得过于顺畅，往往是个坏征兆。 学习感到轻松时，你通常是在重读、辨认、点头附和。这带来舒适感而非真能力。学习感到困难时，你往往在进行提取、生成或间隔练习。那种不适感正是知识留存的关键。 测试效应研究是个例证，间隔练习和交错学习也是。它们都有个恼人的共同点：练习当下的体验更糟糕。 人工智能让工作变得更顺畅，减少了停顿、死胡同和"等等，这为什么不行"的循环。 而大量学习正发生在这个循环里。 自动化研究还指出监控问题：当系统通常正常运行时，人类的监控会减少，越来越难察觉故障。Parasuraman和Riley提出的误用概念就包含自满和警惕性下降。 将这些结合起来，你会得到危险的组合： 更少生成 更少提取 更少监控 更多流畅 更多信任

Then you hit the moment that requires an internal model.

Debugging is a good example. You can’t debug by vibes. You need a chain of reasoning about what should happen, what did happen, and where the divergence likely lives. That chain comes from having built similar chains before.

People assume the danger is “hallucinations.” That’s real, but it’s the loud risk. The quieter risk is that you stop doing the kind of thinking that makes you resilient.

I’m not arguing for some romantic version of suffering. A lot of struggle is wasted time. I’ve wasted plenty of it.

I’m saying there’s a category of friction that’s doing a job, and AI removes it by default.

Why Smooth is a Warning Sign

It’s hard to accept, but when you’re focused on output, feeling like the learning process is going smoothly is often a bad sign.

When studying feels easy, you’re usually rereading, recognizing, nodding along. That produces comfort, not capability. When studying feels harder, you’re often retrieving, generating, or spacing practice. That discomfort is part of why it sticks.

The testing effect research is one example. Another is spacing. Another is interleaving. They all share the same annoying feature: the practice feels worse in the moment.

AI makes work feel smoother. It reduces pauses. It reduces dead ends. It reduces the “wait, why isn’t this working” loop.

That loop is where a lot of learning lives.

Automation research also points to a monitoring problem: when a system usually works, humans monitor it less, and they get worse at noticing when it fails. Parasuraman and Riley’s misuse concept includes complacency and reduced vigilance.

Put those together and you get a nasty combo:

  • Less generation

  • Less retrieval

  • Less monitoring

  • More fluency

  • More trust

我在小团队和业余项目里见过这种情况，不是因为人们粗心，而是因为他们太忙了。大家因快速交付而受奖赏，却不会因为一个月后能从头重建整个系统获得奖励。 别误会，我喜欢这些AI工具。我每天都在用。它们确实让我交付得更快。但我也注意到，如果总是让模型替我打初稿，我会越来越懒得在脑中构建完整的系统框架。 我发现自己写作时就是这样。 我会让AI生成一段文字，心想“嗯，差不多就是这个意思”，粘贴过来就继续往下写。然后有人针对其中某个观点提出尖锐质疑，那一刻真是糟糕——我发现自己竟认同了一段并未真正消化的句子。 这得怪我自己。 但这也像是工具必然导致的结果。 再讲个混乱的小故事。有次我和朋友开发一个简单的薪资计算器，纯属周末消遣，和工作无关。我们为“四舍五入该在扣税前还是扣税后进行”争论不休。窗外下着雨，群聊里有人不停发梗图，好像我们没在认真赶工似的。于是我用模型生成了某个不太熟悉国家的税务逻辑。 它生成的代码看起来挺像样：变量命名规范、注释清晰，连边界情况都考虑了。 一周后用户发来邮件：“你们的净工资计算结果差了大约70欧元。” 我们追溯发现，模型采用了一个曾经正确但已过时的阈值标准。我本该核对税法原文的，但没有。看到整洁的代码就放下了戒心。 这个错误并不能证明AI让人变笨，它揭示了一个更细微却恼人的事实：正因为输出结果看起来完整无缺，人们更容易跳过验证环节。 当然，我也见过相反的情况——有人把AI当导师，强迫自己解释每个步骤，反而学得更快。所以影响并非必然，关键在于使用者的姿态。 我目前的应对体系（虽不完美但真实）

Do not get me wrong, I like these AI tools. I use them every day. I’ve shipped faster because of them. I also notice that if I let the model do the first draft of my thinking too often, I get lazier about holding the whole system in my head.

I catch myself doing it with writing.

I’ll ask for a paragraph, think “yeah that’s basically it,” paste it, and move on. Then someone asks me a sharp question about a claim inside it, and I have that awful moment where I realize I agreed with a sentence I didn’t fully earn.

That’s on me.
It also feels like a predictable outcome of the tool.

One more messy story, I was building a simple salary calculator with a friend, just a weekend thing, nothing tied to my job. We were half arguing about whether the rounding should happen before or after deductions. It was raining. Someone kept sending memes in the group chat like we were not actively trying to finish. I used the model to generate the tax logic for one country I didn’t know well.

It produced something that looked correct. Variable names, comments, even edge cases.

A week later a user emailed: “Your net pay is off by about 70 euros.”

We traced it back. The model had assumed a threshold that used to be true but wasn’t anymore. I should’ve checked the source law table. I didn’t. I saw tidy code and felt safe.

That mistake doesn’t prove AI makes you dumb. It proves something smaller and more annoying. That makes it easier to skip verification because the output looks finished.

And yes, I’ve also seen the opposite, where AI helped someone learn faster because they used it like a tutor and forced themselves to explain each step. So the effect isn’t automatic, but it depends on posture.

My Current System (Imperfect but Real)

不要禁止AI，而是有意识地约束其使用，以保持学习循环的完整性。

这是我曾采用、至今仍偶有失误的一套方法。

item.title: 你不需要动力。你需要清除阻碍你的障碍。
item.description:
你远未触及自己能够采取的行动。

许多人认为现状与理想之间的差距是动力问题。他们看TED演讲（像我一样），听关于寻找“人生意义”的播客，不断吸收关于自律和驱动力的内容。

现实却不同。你有责任在身，时间有限，存在真实的限制。

但你完全可以在无需“获得动力”的情况下彻底改变产出。

你只需要明白动力究竟在弥补什么。

我观察到持续行动者的一个共同模式：他们并不比你更有动力。他们不会醒来时更受鼓舞，也不拥有你所缺乏的某种神奇热情储备。

他们只是消除了那些让开始变得不可能的隐形阻力。

关于阻力、行动，以及为何你听过的所有动力理论都是本末倒置，我想分享几个观点。

我花了数年才明白这点。无论尝试什么方法，我都无法保持动力。我读了一本又一本关于动力的书，却收效甚微。或许20个建议里只有1个真正有用。

以下方法对我有效，说不定也适合你。

为何动力看似必需（实则不然）

“行动之阻促进行动。挡路之石即成路。”
——马可·奥勒留

你的大脑是为生存优化的能量管理系统。

每个你考虑采取的行动都会经过快过意识的成本效益分析。大脑会计算：这需要多少能量？确定的结果是什么？风险有多大？

你的大脑以快过意识的速度持续进行成本效益分析

这应当令你警醒。它令我警醒。

因为这意味着：你的大脑正在主动寻找不行动的理由。它搜寻不确定性、困难、复杂性，并利用这些信号为不作为辩护。

这不是缺陷，而是特性。 在人类二十万年的进化历程中，节能机制让我们得以存活。不必要的行动意味着热量浪费，不确定的结果可能招致死亡。你的祖先在冲进黑暗森林前犹豫片刻，才得以幸存并将基因传递下来。 你继承的大脑生来就避免非必要的行动。 回想上次你需要启动重要事项的时刻：一个工作项目、一场艰难对话、一次生活方式转变。 你的脑海是否浮现出这些念头： 或许我该先研究最佳方案 现在状态不对 等有充足时间再好好处理 先处理完这些琐事再说 我需要更充分的准备才能开始 我……（此处可填入任何你的借口） 这并非懒惰。 这是二十万年进化程序在执行优化协议。 问题在于： 现代生活需要的恰恰与祖先的生存法则相反。 当今的成功需要在不确定时采取行动，进步需要在你感觉未准备好时就开始，成就意味着在结果未卜时依然向前。 你的大脑将此视为威胁。 于是它执行既定程序：制造阻力、怀疑、犹豫，以及那种模糊的“还不是时候”的感觉。 陷阱在于： 你总试图用动力来压制这种阻力。 你并非因缺乏动力而无法行动。 你正在消耗动力，只为突破大脑构筑的无形屏障。 多数建议千篇一律，但这里不同。订阅获取引发思考的洞见。 阻力的三种类型 在消除阻力前，我们需要认清真正的对手。 多数人将阻力视为单一的整体，那种“我现在不想做”的模糊感受。 但阻力自有结构，由不同成分组成，每种都需要独特的解决方案。 启动能量阻力

For 200,000 years of human evolution, conserving energy kept us alive. Unnecessary movement meant wasted calories. Uncertain outcomes meant potential death. Your ancestors who hesitated before running into the dark forest survived to pass on their genes.

You inherited a brain designed to avoid action unless absolutely necessary.

Think about the last time you needed to start something important. A work project. A difficult conversation. A lifestyle change.

Your mind generated a list:

  • Maybe I should research the best approach first

  • I’m not in the right headspace right now

  • I should wait until I have more time to do it properly

  • Let me just handle these smaller things first

  • I need to be more prepared before I begin

  • I…. add any of your excuses.

That’s not you being lazy.

That’s 200,000 years of evolutionary programming running its optimization protocol.

The problem is that modern life requires the opposite of what kept your ancestors alive. Success today demands action in the face of uncertainty. Progress requires starting before you feel ready. Achievement means moving when the outcome isn’t guaranteed.

Your brain experiences this as a threat.

So it does what it’s designed to do: it generates resistance. Doubt. Hesitation. A vague sense of “not yet.”

And here’s the trap: motivation is what you use to overpower that resistance.

You aren’t failing to act because you lack motivation.

You’re burning motivation just to overcome the invisible barriers your brain has constructed.

Most advice sounds the same. This won’t. Subscribe for ideas that make you think.

The Three Types of Resistance

Before we can eliminate resistance, we need to understand what we’re actually fighting.

Most people experience resistance as a single, monolithic force. That vague sense of “I don’t want to do this right now.”

But resistance has structure. It has components. And each component requires a different solution.

Activation Energy Resistance

这是意图与行动之间的鸿沟。明明知道该开始了，却还在刷手机、整理书桌，或者突然想起十七件"紧急"任务。 物理学对此有个术语：活化能。启动化学反应所需的最小能量。 你的大脑将每个新行动视为需要足够能量才能开始的化学反应。任务看起来越复杂，所需的活化能就越高。 心理抗拒 这是大脑对受控感的过敏反应。即使是你自己设定的目标，即使你真心想要那个结果，部分心智仍会反抗这种"必须做"的义务感。 你一定经历过：周五还兴致勃勃的项目，周一早晨突然变得令人窒息；当初满怀热情许下的承诺，如今却像一道枷锁。 大脑正通过抗拒你自己的决定，来保护你的自主感。 不确定性瘫痪 当大脑无法清晰预测结果时就会发生这种情况。你有十二种可能方案，不确定哪种正确，不知道自己是否具备所需技能，无法想象最终状态。 于是大脑选择了最安全的选项。 那就是什么都不做。 但大多数效率建议都错在这里：它们告诉你要用意志力、自律，当然还有动力来克服这些阻力。 这就像拉着手刹开车。没错，如果你把油门踩得够狠，或许能前进。但你在消耗燃料对抗本不该存在的摩擦力。 那么到底缺了什么？ 答案在于：你需要的不是更大的推力。 你需要松开手刹。 研究专业作家给我的启示 我一直对"奋斗文化"对动力的痴迷抱有某种反感。

Physics has a term for this: activation energy. The minimum energy required to start a chemical reaction.

Your brain treats every new action as a reaction that needs sufficient energy to begin. The more complex the task appears, the higher the activation energy required.

Psychological Reactance

This is your brain’s allergic reaction to feeling controlled. Even when you’re the one creating the expectation, even when you genuinely want the outcome, part of your mind rebels against the obligation.

You’ve experienced this: the project you were excited about on Friday suddenly feels oppressive on Monday morning. The commitment you made with enthusiasm now feels like a constraint.

Your brain is protecting your sense of autonomy by making you resist your own decisions.

Uncertainty Paralysis

This is what happens when your brain can’t predict the outcome clearly enough. You have twelve possible approaches. You’re not sure which is correct. You don’t know if you have the skills required. You can’t visualize the end state.

So your brain selects the safest option.

Which is nothing.

But here’s what most productivity advice gets wrong: it tells you to overcome these forces with willpower, discipline, and yes, motivation.

That’s like trying to drive a car with the parking brake engaged. Sure, if you press the accelerator hard enough, you might move forward. But you’re burning fuel fighting friction that shouldn’t exist.

So what’s missing?

The answer lies in the fact that you don’t need more force.

You need to remove the brake.

What I Learned Studying Professional Writers

I’ve always had some form of aversion toward hustle culture’s obsession with motivation.

Instagram上的励志语录，清晨自律视频，那些效率导师们信誓旦旦地说：只要足够深刻地找到你的"内在驱动力"，行动就会毫不费力。 直到我开始研究专业创作者/作家实际的工作方式，才明白为什么这些建议对我从来不起作用。 欧内斯特·海明威每天早晨都写作，无论是否有灵感。他会在写到一半时停笔，这样第二天开始只需要极低的启动能量。 村上春树在写作前会跑步，用身体习惯完全绕过大脑的谈判阶段。 史蒂文·普莱斯菲尔德将阻力称为"地球上最毒的力量"，他像士兵报到一样坐在书桌前，完全不顾自己的感受。 这些人并非拥有超人的动力。 他们是系统性地消除了对动力的需求。 当我逆向分析他们的方法时发现： 他们不与阻力对抗。 他们不试图用灵感或意志力压制它。 他们建立了让阻力变得无关紧要的体系。 海明威的半句停顿？那是降低启动能量。他并非每天从零开始，而是完成一个句子，这几乎不需要能量。 村上春树的日常习惯？那是心理抗拒管理。他不是在决定是否写作，而是在执行包含写作的固定流程。 普莱斯菲尔德的军事化方法？那是消除不确定性。不存在"是否写作"或"何时写作"的问题，这些决定根本不存在。 他们共同的秘诀： 识别出自己特定的阻力模式，并建立应对机制。 不是动力，不是自律，不是灵感。 而是战略性地消除阻力。 这里有个令人不安的真相：你之所以没有这样做，是因为它需要诚实的自我诊断。看励志视频获得短暂激励，比精确分析阻碍你开始的心理机制要容易得多。 但正是这种

It wasn’t until I started studying how professional creators/writers actually work that I understood why this advice never worked for me.

Ernest Hemingway wrote every morning, whether he felt inspired or not. He stopped mid-sentence so starting the next day required minimal activation energy.

Haruki Murakami runs before writing, using physical routine to bypass his brain’s negotiation phase entirely.

Steven Pressfield calls resistance “the most toxic force on the planet” and treats showing up to his desk like a soldier reporting for duty, regardless of how he feels.

These aren’t people with superhuman motivation.

They’re people who’ve systematically eliminated the need for it.

Here’s what I discovered when I reverse engineered their approaches: they don’t fight resistance. They don’t try to overpower it with inspiration or willpower.

They’ve built systems that make resistance irrelevant.

Hemingway’s mid-sentence stop? That’s activation energy reduction. He’s not starting from zero each morning. He’s completing a sentence, which requires almost no energy.

Murakami’s physical routine? That’s psychological reactance management. He’s not making a decision about whether to write. He’s executing a sequence that includes writing.

Pressfield’s militaristic approach? That’s uncertainty elimination. There’s no question about IF he writes or WHEN he writes. Those decisions don’t exist.

The secret they share: they’ve identified their specific resistance patterns and built countermeasures.

Not motivation. Not discipline. Not inspiration.

Strategic friction removal.

And here’s the uncomfortable truth: the reason you haven’t done this is because it requires honest self-diagnosis. It’s easier to watch a motivation video and feel temporarily energized than to map the exact psychological mechanisms preventing you from starting.

But that 临时能量代价高昂.

它有限且会耗尽。每次你燃烧它来克服阻力，都在训练大脑相信行动需要巨大能量。

因此，持续行动的最佳方法并非寻找更好的开始理由

而是消除不开始的理由

我曾以为自己缺乏自律，后来发现只是把每件事都变得不必要的困难

大脑的真实运作机制

人生中有几个瞬间令我记忆犹新

比如在停车场车里坐了四十分钟，纠结那个拖延三周的电话——明明只需五分钟，号码就在手边，措辞早已想好

却不断编织着"现在不合适"的精致借口

这段经历让我明白：阻力无关理性，关乎神经机制.

前中扣带皮层

大脑中有个称为前中扣带皮层的区域，堪称"困难探测器"

当你面临挑战、艰难抉择或忍受不适时它便激活。研究表明，经常挑战自我者该区域会出现结构性变化

这个区域不区分生理困难与心理阻力。对前中扣带皮层而言，起草棘手邮件所需的启动能量与爬楼梯的费力感完全相同

多数人遭遇阻力时会理解为："此刻任务太难，我需要更充分准备"但那种感受与实际难度无关

只与感知到的阻力成正比

多巴胺预测误差

大脑运行依赖名为

多巴胺的神经递质，而多数人对其存在根本误解，以为关乎愉悦或奖赏实则不然

多巴胺关乎预期

Dopamine is about prediction当现实超出预期时，大脑会释放多巴胺。当你本不抱期待却有所收获时，当你预想困难却体验轻松时。 每次你滑动社交媒体而非开始任务，大脑都会获得微量的多巴胺刺激。 预期努力（零）与实际努力（零）完全吻合。完美预测。 每次你整理书桌而非启动项目时，情况相同。预想的低努力与实际低努力匹配。多巴胺确认了你的选择。 但当你终于强迫自己开始回避已久的任务时呢？大脑曾预测巨大困难。而有时一旦开始，情况并不如想象中糟糕。 多巴胺本应如潮水般涌来，对吗？ 然而在回避某事时，机制并不如此运作。因为你已训练大脑认定：这项特定任务需要巨大的启动能量。预测误差过大，大脑不再信任这个信号。 显著性网络劫持现象 大脑中存在一个名为"显著性网络"的系统，负责判定何事值得关注。它本应突出重要相关信息，过滤干扰杂音。 但实际情况是：每次你回避任务，显著性网络就将其标记为威胁。不是重要，而是威胁。 下次你考虑启动任务时，该网络会触发与遭遇捕食者相同的神经模式。你的注意力被劫持了。你会突然注意到所有看似更紧迫、更安全、更即时满足的事物。 你并非软弱，也非缺乏自律。你的大脑已被训练成将最重要的工作视为威胁。 而所谓动力，不过是你用来暂时关闭威胁反应的紧急制动系统。 多年来我领悟到：你可以重塑这些系统。不是通过意志力，而是通过系统性的阻力削减。 摩擦消除方案 你需要一套系统。

Every time you scroll social media instead of starting your task, your brain gets a tiny dopamine hit.

Expected effort (zero) matched by actual effort (zero). Perfect prediction.

Every time you reorganize your desk instead of beginning your project, same thing. Low effort predicted, low effort experienced. Dopamine confirms your choice.

But when you finally force yourself to start the task you’ve been avoiding? Your brain predicted massive difficulty. And sometimes, once you begin, it’s not as bad as you thought.

Dopamine should flood your system, right?

Except it doesn’t work that way when you’ve been avoiding something. Because you’ve trained your brain that THIS specific task requires enormous activation energy. The prediction error is too large. Your brain doesn’t trust it.

The Salience Network Hijacking

Your brain has a network called the salience network that determines what deserves your attention. It’s supposed to highlight important, relevant information and filter out noise.

But here’s what happens: every time you avoid a task, your salience network marks it as threatening. Not important. Threatening.

The next time you consider starting it, your network triggers the same neural pattern as encountering a predator. Your attention gets hijacked. You suddenly notice everything else that seems more urgent, more safe, more immediately rewarding.

You’re not weak, you’re not undisciplined. Your brain has been trained to perceive your most important work as a threat.

And motivation is the emergency override system you’re using to temporarily shut down that threat response.

What I learned over the years is that you can retrain these systems. Not through willpower. Through systematic resistance reduction.

The Friction Elimination Protocol

You need a system.

不是动力仪式，不是晨间惯例，不是效率技巧——这些对我从来无效。

一套针对阻碍行动的具体抵抗模式的诊断与清除方案。

我启动每个重要项目时，都会在阻力点演变成障碍前识别它们。多数人等到卡住时才疑惑为何无法突破。

第一步：阻力映射练习

残酷地认清三件事：

你此刻在逃避什么？列出所有明知该做却未开始的任务、项目或行动。要具体。“处理工作”是无效的，“撰写客户方案初稿”才有效。

你为此编造了什么借口？针对每项逃避的任务，写下你考虑启动时的真实念头：“我需要更充分准备”“时间不够好好完成”“应该等不那么累时再做”。

怎样能让开始变得毫不费力？为每项任务设定最小启动动作。不是完整任务，只是切入点：“打开文档”而非“写完方案”。

请记住：你分析的不是任务本身，而是对任务的心理反应。

任务可能客观上很简单，但若大脑将其标记为高阻力，简单也无济于事。

加入“反阻力”练习：写下大脑生成的所有拖延理由。每个借口，每种辩解。

所有“再等等”——让它们显形于纸面，你会看清这些只是固定模式，而非它们伪装成的真理。

第二步：启动能量审计

大脑将决策视为消耗。关于如何开始、何时开始、先做什么的每个选择，都会在实际工作前燃烧认知能量。

解决方案是：在需要决策前就消除选择。

针对最高阻力任务，建立预设决策协议：

  • 明确何时开始（基于时间触发，而非感觉触发）。

  • 明确工作地点（固定场所消除空间选择）

  • 明确第一步动作（打开电脑/打开文档/写下第一句话）

  • 明确最短工作时长（建议15分钟，而非“做完为止”）

这无关自律，而是消除让大脑产生协商空间的选择

第三步：确定性构建法

大脑抗拒不确定远胜于困难——停滞常因不知何为“完成”

消除不确定瘫痪的最佳方式：在开始前定义完成标准

针对每个逃避的任务：

  • 具体完成状态是什么？（非“更好”“差不多”，而是可验证标准）

  • 最低合格线是什么？（底线而非上限）

  • 哪些是必要信息？哪些是以研究为名的拖延？

从最低目标开始——非志向低微，而是让大脑确信完成可能

完成最低目标即产生动力，动力改变大脑对努力的预判，预判降低则阻力消退

最低目标非终点，而是绕过大脑威胁反应的机制

第四步：环境强制函数

所处环境非减阻即增阻——手机触手可及、桌面堆积半成品、舒适座椅诱发分心

若需意志力维持专注，终将败北

环境设计应使正确行动比错误行动更轻松

深度工作需：

  • 手机置于他处（非静音，需物理隔离）

  • 单任务可视（其他项目全部关闭或隐藏）

  • 适度不适感（非惩罚性，但避免安逸致拖延）

放弃手机对我来说很难，有时至今仍是如此，所以我给自己买了一个带计时器的塑料盒。我会把手机锁在里面，设置一小时，必须等满一小时才能拿回手机。这是我能限制自己不停查看手机的唯一方法。 对于想逃避的任务： 预先打开你需要的具体文件/工具/文档 关闭所有其他应用程序 为你设定的最短工作时间设置计时器 这就是你唯一需要的效率建议： 让开始比逃避更省力 我们的抗阻力框架由以下部分组成： 已识别的心理模式（你知道自己在对抗什么） 消除决策（不给谈判机会） 明确完成标准（避免不确定性瘫痪） 精心设计的环境（让阻力为你服务而非阻碍你） 这创造了一个紧密的反馈循环，促使你的大脑重新计算努力预期，从而降低启动能量，让开始变得更容易，并向你的大脑证明之前的阻力是被夸大的。这就是基础，这就是消除动机需求的关键。 为什么阻力其实是信息 开始重要事情前感到犹豫是正常的 面对不确定性时产生怀疑是应该的 注意到现状与目标之间的差距是必然的 问题不在于你感受到阻力 问题在于你被教导将阻力解读为你还没准备好、能力不足或动力不够的证据 当你决定做对自己真正重要的事情时，你到底期待发生什么？ 难道你认为经过二十万年进化、擅长节约能量和回避不确定性的大脑会乖乖配合？以为每天醒来都会灵感迸发、毫无阻力、轻松自如地朝着目标前进？ 最成功的人不会在阻力面前退缩 他们预料到阻力，将其视为正在尝试值得付出努力的艰难之事的确认。

For avoided tasks:

  • Pre-open the exact file/tool/document you need

  • Close every other application

  • Set a timer for the minimum session you defined

That is the only piece of productivity advice you need: make starting require less effort than avoiding.

Our anti-resistance frame is composed of:

  • Mapped psychological patterns (you know what you’re fighting)

  • Eliminated decisions (no negotiation opportunities)

  • Defined completion (no uncertainty paralysis)

  • Engineered environment (friction works for you, not against you)

This creates a tight feedback loop that encourages your brain to recalculate effort predictions, which reduces activation energy, which makes starting easier, which proves to your brain that resistance was disproportionate.

That’s the foundation. That’s what eliminates the need for motivation.

Why Resistance is Actually Information

You’re supposed to feel hesitation before starting something important.

You’re supposed to experience doubt when facing uncertainty.

You’re supposed to notice the gap between where you are and where you’re trying to go.

The problem isn’t that you feel resistance. The problem is that you’ve been taught to interpret resistance as evidence that you’re not ready, not capable, or not motivated enough.

What in the world did you expect to happen when you decided to do something that actually matters to you?

Did you think your brain, optimized for 200,000 years to conserve energy and avoid uncertainty, would just cooperate? That you’d wake up inspired every day, resistance-free, flowing effortlessly toward your goals?

The most successful people don’t flinch at resistance.

They expect it. They recognize it as confirmation they’re attempting something difficult enough to be worthwhile.

行动参与度分不同层次： 第一层 是等待有动力再行动。让情绪状态决定行为。这必然导致不稳定，因为情绪天生就是多变的。 第二层 是用自律压倒动力。即使不想做也强迫自己行动。这方法有效，但极其消耗能量。你正在耗费意志力对抗自身的阻力。 第三层 是通过消除阻力，让动力和自律都变得不再必要。 许多人卡在第一层和第二层之间，耗费巨大能量试图变得更自律、更有动力、更稳定。 他们从未想过，真正的关键在于减少阻力，而非增加推力。 把你的大脑想象成正在学习导航的自动驾驶汽车。数月甚至数年来，它接收到的信息是：某些任务需要巨大努力。每次你犹豫、拖延或需要动力才能启动时，都在强化这种模式。 但模式可以重新训练。 每次你顶着阻力开始行动，并发现事情不如预想中糟糕时，都是在更新大脑的算法。 每次你降低启动能量、让开始变得更容易时，都是在教会大脑新的模式。 最终，那些曾经需要动力的事情会变得自动发生。不是因为你变得更自律，而是因为你的大脑重新计算了所需努力，并停止制造阻力。 我多希望可以告诉每位读者：你们能立刻消除所有阻力。 但如果真是这样，持续行动的能力将失去全部意义。 你必须经历这个过程：测绘你的阻力，消除你的摩擦，向你的大脑证明——行动并不需要它预判的那么费力。 行动者与等待动力者的区别，不在于内在力量。 而在于系统性地消除阻力。

Level 1 is waiting until you feel motivated. Letting your emotional state determine your behavior. This guarantees inconsistency because emotions are variable by design.

Level 2 is using discipline to override motivation. Forcing yourself to act despite not feeling like it. This works, but it’s energetically expensive. You’re spending willpower to fight your own resistance.

Level 3 is removing the need for both motivation and discipline by eliminating the resistance that made them necessary.

Many people are stuck between Level 1 and Level 2, burning enormous energy trying to become more disciplined, more motivated, more consistent.

They never consider that the game is removing friction, not increasing force.

Think of your brain like a self-driving car learning to navigate. For months, maybe years, it has received input that certain tasks require massive effort. Every time you’ve hesitated, procrastinated, or needed motivation to start, you’ve reinforced that pattern.

But patterns can be retrained.

Every time you start despite resistance and discover it wasn’t as bad as predicted, you’re updating the model. Every time you reduce activation energy and make starting easier, you’re teaching your brain a new pattern.

Eventually, the tasks that once required motivation become automatic. Not because you’ve become more disciplined, but because your brain has recalculated the effort required and stopped generating resistance.

I wish I could tell you that everyone reading this can eliminate all resistance immediately.

But if that were the case, the ability to act consistently would lose all meaning.

You must go through the process of mapping your resistance, eliminating your friction, and proving to your brain that action doesn’t require the force it’s been predicting.

The difference between people who act and people who wait for motivation isn’t internal strength.

It’s systematic friction removal.

而你早已万事俱备，只待启程。 我仍会不时察觉——无论是坐在办公室还是家中书桌前，那种熟悉的沉重感总会悄然袭来。总觉得在开始前必须“准备就绪”，总想等到心境转变再行动。 后来我明白，自己等待的并非某种感觉，而是在寻找尚未扫除的障碍。 好的思想通过人与人传递，而非算法。若你身边有人会喜欢这些文字，不妨分享给他们。 分享 不容错过的精选文章：

I still catch myself sometimes, sitting at my desk at work or home, feeling that old familiar weight. The sense that I need to be “ready” before I start. That I should wait until I feel different.

Then I remember that I’m not waiting for a feeling. I’m looking for friction I haven’t removed yet.

Good ideas spread through people, not algorithms. Share if you know someone who’d enjoy this.
